inlineContent.text: The digi.me private sharing platform empowers developers to make use of user data from thousands of sources in a way that fully respects a user’s privacy, and whilst conforming to GDPR. Our consent driven solution allows you to define exactly what terms you want data by, and the user to see these completely transparently, allowing them to make an informed choice as to whether to grant consent or not.
package to the dependencies within your application’s
We do not currently support linking DigiMeSDK as a Static Library.

We have taken the most common use case for the digi.me Private Sharing SDK and compiled a quick start guide, which you can find below. Nonetheless, we implore you to
This example will show you how to configure the SDK, and get you up and running with

content.text: 1. Obtaining your Contract ID, Application ID & Private Key:

inlineContent.text: To access the digi.me platform, you need to obtain an
for your application. You can get yours by filling out the registration form
In a production environment, you will also be required to obtain your own
from digi.me support. However, for sandbox purposes, you can use one of the contracts from the example projects (see
Because the digi.me Private Sharing SDK hooks into your browser to receive callbacks, you are required to forward the
event through to the SDK so that it may process responses. In your application’s delegate (typically

code: func scene(_ scene: UIScene, openURLContexts URLContexts: Set<UIOpenURLContext>) {

inlineContent.text: And register custom URL scheme so that your app can receive the callback from Digi.me app. Still in
is the object you will primarily interface with to use the SDK. It is instantiated with a
. The below code snippet shows you how to combine all this to get a configured

code: let configuration = try Configuration(appId: "YOUR_APP_ID", contractId: "YOUR_CONTRACT_ID", privateKey: privateKey)

inlineContent.text: Before you can access a user’s data, you must obtain their consent. This is achieved by calling

on your client object. You need to provide a service identifier for which you want to request access to; this can be found by referring the the service definitions in the developer docs or my using the

code: digiMe.authorize(serviceId: service?.identifier, readOptions: nil) { result in
// store credentials and continue on to fetch data.

inlineContent.text: If a user grants consent, a session will be created under the hood; this is used by subsequent calls to get data. If the user denies consent, an error stating this is returned. See
Once you have a session, you can request data. We strive to make this as simple as possible, so expose a single method to do so:

code: digiMe.readAllFiles(credentials: credentials, readOptions: nil) { result in
// Access data or metadata of file.
// Handle success and update stored credentials as these may have been refreshed.

inlineContent.text: For each file, the first ‘file handler’ block will be called. If the download was successful, you will receive a
object. If the download fails, an error.

Once all files are downloaded, the second block will be invoked to inform you of this. In the case that the data stream is interrupted, or if the session obtained above isn’t valid (it may have expired, for example), you will receive an error in the second block. See
which contains the file’s raw data along with the

property. For files with JSON or image mime types, there are convenience methods to decode that raw data into the appropriate format, so that you can easily extract the values you need to power your app. In addition,
is available describing the file. In this example, as the data comes from external services, the metadata will be a
type describing the file’s contents and details of associated service.
Note that we also expose other methods if you prefer to manage this process yourself.
digi.me prides itself in offering our SDKs completely open source, under the
; we welcome contributions from all developers.
We ask that when contributing, you ensure your changes meet our
are just a small part of the power digi.me Private Sharing gives to data consumers such as yourself. We highly encourage you to explore the
for more in-depth examples and guides, as well as troubleshooting advice and showcases of the plethora of capabilities on offer.
Additionally, there are a number of example apps built on digi.me in the examples folder. Feel free to have a look at those to get an insight into the power of Private Sharing.

abstract.text: Cache for securely storing credentials in the keychain
Information about a service data source
Represents an available file from digi.me library
Scope used to limit service-based data retrieval to specified services and a specified time ranges
Allows metadata for raw files, which will be written to user’s library,
The logging levels which will be logged

Whilst using the SDK, you may encounter a number of errors. Some of these, we will attempt to recover from on your behalf, however, there are a large number that will require you to take some kind of action.
Handles callbacks via inter-app communication such as deeplinks
The account relating to a service data source user has added to digi.me library
Represents a file retrieved from library

We are open to, and grateful for, any contributions made by the community. When contributing to this repository, please first discuss the change you wish to make via issue, email, or any other method with the owners of this repository before making a change.
The entry point to the SDK
Represents a service scope with which data requests can be limited to
Represents an object scope with which data requests can be limited to
Reason why connecting to source or importing data from source into user’s library failed
Period of time (in seconds) used for attempting to retrieve new data from all service data sources.
In case sync is not completed within the specified duration, a partial account status will be reported in
Represents a list of files available from digi.me library

digi.me prides itself in normalizing data from a huge array of sources into common ontologies, however, as a data portability facilitator, we support the flow of data in both directions - from the user to you, and from you back to the user.
The status of synchronizing data from a service-based source into user’s library
Metadata for a file with mapped service data
Block signature for custom log handlers
Details of a source being synchronized
Represents a time range scope with which data requests can be limited to
Details which service data source accounts the user has added.
Describes a country for a service data source
Options used to configure session for reading data from service-based data sources
Represents a service group scope with which data requests can be limited to
Log levels which are available to be logged
Describes the group for a service data source
Metadata for a file with raw data (typically one which has been written to library)
Info for services and related groups
Short description of a service relating to user’s account
Credentials for accessing user’s digi.me library
